title: Psalms Chapter 139 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 139 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 139 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 139.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 139?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:1 states it is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:2, what does the LORD know about the psalmist?
questions.correctAnswer: His downsitting and uprising
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:2 says the LORD knows the psalmist's downsitting and uprising.

questions.question: What does God understand from afar, according to Psalms 139:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The psalmist's thoughts
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:2 states God understands the psalmist's thoughts afar off.

questions.question: What does Psalms 139:4 say about the words on the psalmist's tongue?
questions.correctAnswer: God knows them altogether
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:4 states there is not a word in the tongue but God knows it altogether.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:5, what has God done to the psalmist?
options: Beset him behind and before and laid His hand upon him
questions.correctAnswer: Beset him behind and before and laid His hand upon him
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:5 describes God as besetting the psalmist behind and before and laying His hand upon him.

questions.question: Where does Psalms 139:7 say the psalmist cannot go to escape God's spirit?
questions.correctAnswer: Anywhere
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:7 asks where one can go to flee from God's spirit, implying nowhere.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 139:8 says if the psalmist ascends to heaven, God is not there.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:8 says if the psalmist ascends to heaven, God is there.

questions.question: What does Psalms 139:13 say God has possessed?
questions.correctAnswer: The reins
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:13 states God has possessed the psalmist's reins and covered him in the womb.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:14, how is the psalmist made?
questions.correctAnswer: Fearfully and wonderfully
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:14 says the psalmist is fearfully and wonderfully made.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 139:16 says, 'Thine eyes did see my substance, yet being _______;'
questions.correctAnswer: unperfect
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:16 uses the word 'unperfect' to describe the psalmist's substance seen by God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:18, how many are God's thoughts toward the psalmist?
questions.correctAnswer: More than the sand
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:18 says God's thoughts are more in number than the sand.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 139:19 asks God to slay the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:19 says surely God will slay the wicked.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do in Psalms 139:23?
options: Search me and know my heart
questions.correctAnswer: Search me and know my heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:23 asks God to search the psalmist and know his heart and thoughts.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 139:12 says darkness is completely hidden from God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:12 says darkness hideth not from God; night shines as day to Him.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:10, what will God's right hand do?
questions.correctAnswer: Hold the psalmist
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:10 says God's right hand shall hold the psalmist even in the uttermost parts of the sea.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 139 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 139 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling isolated and worries that God might not be with them in their struggles. Based on Psalms 139, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God is always present, even in our darkest moments
God only knows us when we are in church
God is far away when we sin
God only helps those who are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: God is always present, even in our darkest moments
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:7-12 teaches that no matter where we go or what darkness surrounds us, God's Spirit is there and the darkness is as light to Him. This assures us of His constant presence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139 encourage us to approach God in prayer when we desire personal spiritual growth and examination?
options: Ask God to search and know your heart and lead you in the right way
Focus only on praying for others, not yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to search and know your heart and lead you in the right way
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:23-24 explicitly invites God to search the heart and lead the believer in the way everlasting, highlighting humility and dependence on God for guidance.

questions.question: In the context of family life, how does Psalms 139 affirm the value of children and the care God has for them?
options: God knows and fashions us even before birth with great care
Children are a burden and unknown to God
God only cares for adults who serve Him
Children must earn God's favor through works
questions.correctAnswer: God knows and fashions us even before birth with great care
questions.explanation: Verses 13-16 show that God formed us in the mother's womb and knew all our days before we were born, emphasizing the sacredness of life and God's intimate care.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139 teach us about integrity and honesty in daily life and work?
options: God knows all our actions and thoughts, so we should live with integrity
We can hide our dishonesty from God
Only public actions matter to God
Integrity is optional as long as others don't see
questions.correctAnswer: God knows all our actions and thoughts, so we should live with integrity
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 describe God's complete knowledge of our ways, thoughts, and words, encouraging believers to live honestly knowing nothing is hidden from God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with feelings of inadequacy and wonders if God truly values them. What truth from Psalms 139 would you share?
options: We are fearfully and wonderfully made by God, and His works are marvelous
God only values those without faults
Our worth depends on our achievements
questions.correctAnswer: We are fearfully and wonderfully made by God, and His works are marvelous
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:14 declares that we are wonderfully made and God's works are marvelous, reminding us of our value and God's intentional design.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139 instruct believers to deal with those who oppose God and act wickedly?
options: Hate them with perfect hatred and consider them enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Hate them with perfect hatred and consider them enemies
questions.explanation: Verses 19-22 express a strong rejection of the wicked who oppose God, showing that believers must stand firmly against evil and maintain spiritual discernment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139 encourage humility and contentment in the believer's life?
options: Recognizing God's knowledge is too wonderful to attain
Claiming to fully understand God's plans
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing God's knowledge is too wonderful to attain
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:6 acknowledges that God's knowledge is so high and wonderful it cannot be fully comprehended, encouraging humility before God.

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation and feels overwhelmed. Based on Psalms 139, what truth about God's guidance and support can help them persevere?
options: God's hand will lead and hold us even in distant places
We are left alone in temptation
Only people can help us, not God
Temptation is a sign God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: God's hand will lead and hold us even in distant places
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 affirm that even in the uttermost parts of the sea, God's hand leads and holds us, providing comfort and strength in trials.

questions.question: How can Psalms 139 guide a believer in their attitude toward God’s thoughts and plans for them?
options: God's thoughts toward us are precious and numerous, deserving gratitude
God has few thoughts about us
questions.correctAnswer: God's thoughts toward us are precious and numerous, deserving gratitude
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 emphasize the great number and preciousness of God's thoughts toward us, encouraging thankfulness and trust in His care.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 139, God only knows the words we speak but not the thoughts in our hearts.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:2-4 states that God knows our thoughts from afar and every word on our tongue, showing His full knowledge of both inner thoughts and spoken words.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 139 teaches that we can flee from God's presence if we desire to be alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:7-8 declares there is nowhere we can go from God's Spirit or presence, affirming His constant nearness and sovereignty.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 139 describes God's care for us from the time we were made in secret, ______ and curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth.
options: in the lowest parts of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: in secret
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:15 says our substance was not hidden from God when we were made in secret, emphasizing God's intimate craftsmanship before birth.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139 encourage believers to respond when others take God's name in vain and oppose Him?
options: Grieve and hate those who rise up against God
questions.correctAnswer: Grieve and hate those who rise up against God
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 reveal the psalmist's grief and hatred for those who oppose God, showing a righteous stance against blasphemy and wickedness.

questions.question: How can Psalms 139 help a believer cultivate a spirit of gratitude and praise in their daily life?
options: By recognizing we are fearfully and wonderfully made and praising God for His works
By focusing on our failures and shortcomings
By ignoring God's involvement in our lives
questions.correctAnswer: By recognizing we are fearfully and wonderfully made and praising God for His works
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:14 encourages praise because of God's marvelous creation of each person, inspiring gratitude and worship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139 teach us about God's omniscient care in relation to our life journey and decisions?
options: God is acquainted with all our ways and knows our path
God is unaware of our daily actions
We can hide our true intentions from God
God only cares about major life events
questions.correctAnswer: God is acquainted with all our ways and knows our path
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:3 explains that God encompasses our path and ways, demonstrating His intimate knowledge and care in all aspects of life.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 139 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 139.

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in Psalms 139:7-10, where the psalmist discusses the impossibility of fleeing from God's presence?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:7-10 uses parallelism by presenting contrasting images of ascending to heaven and descending to hell, emphasizing God's omnipresence.

questions.question: In Psalms 139:13, the Hebrew word translated as 'reins' (representing innermost parts) reflects what ancient Near Eastern concept about human anatomy?
options: The seat of emotions and conscience
The physical heart as the center of life
The brain as the source of intellect
The liver as the organ of purification
questions.correctAnswer: The seat of emotions and conscience
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern thought, 'reins' symbolized the inner being, emotions, and conscience, aligning with the Hebrew understanding in Psalms 139:13.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139:16's reference to God writing all members in His book before they existed foreshadow New Testament teachings?
options: It alludes to predestination and God's foreknowledge as seen in Ephesians 1:4
It predicts the Mosaic Law's detailed commandments
It relates to the Goliath narrative as a type
It symbolizes the building of Solomon’s temple
questions.correctAnswer: It alludes to predestination and God's foreknowledge as seen in Ephesians 1:4
questions.explanation: The verse reflects God's intimate foreknowledge and planning of individuals, paralleling New Testament themes of predestination in Ephesians 1:4.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the theme developed in Psalms 139:1-6 regarding God's knowledge of the psalmist?
options: God’s exhaustive and intimate knowledge of the individual's life and thoughts
questions.correctAnswer: God’s exhaustive and intimate knowledge of the individual's life and thoughts
questions.explanation: Verses 1-6 highlight how God searches and knows every aspect of the psalmist, from thoughts to actions, indicating intimate divine knowledge.

questions.question: What is the significance of the contrast between darkness and light in Psalms 139:11-12 within the ancient Hebrew worldview?
options: Darkness and light are equally transparent to God, showing His omniscience
Darkness symbolizes evil and light symbolizes good in a moral dualism
Darkness is associated with ignorance and light with knowledge
Darkness is the absence of God’s presence
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness and light are equally transparent to God, showing His omniscience
questions.explanation: The passage states that darkness and light are alike to God, emphasizing His all-encompassing knowledge beyond human limitations of sight.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:14, what does the phrase 'fearfully and wonderfully made' imply about the nature of human creation?
options: Humans are crafted with awe-inspiring complexity and intentionality
Humans are made to fear God
Humans are created to rule over nature
questions.correctAnswer: Humans are crafted with awe-inspiring complexity and intentionality
questions.explanation: The psalmist praises God for making him with marvelous workmanship, indicating reverence for the intricate design of human life.

questions.question: In Psalms 139:15, the phrase 'curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth' metaphorically refers to what aspect of human development?
options: The hidden, secret formation in the mother's womb
The burial practices in ancient Israel
The creation of Adam from dust
questions.correctAnswer: The hidden, secret formation in the mother's womb
questions.explanation: The verse poetically describes the secret and intricate process of human formation before birth, likened to being wrought in earth's depths.

questions.question: What theological concept does Psalms 139:23-24 emphasize when the psalmist asks God to 'search me' and 'lead me in the way everlasting'?
questions.correctAnswer: Sanctification and divine guidance
questions.explanation: The plea reflects a desire for God’s examination to reveal sin and for guidance on the eternal path, highlighting themes of holiness and discipleship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139:19-22 express the psalmist's attitude towards the wicked and those who oppose God?
options: With strong hatred and a desire for their removal
With pity and calls for repentance
questions.correctAnswer: With strong hatred and a desire for their removal
questions.explanation: The verses express perfect hatred for enemies of God and a plea for their departure, reflecting the psalmist’s zeal for God's honor.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 139:5 employs imagery that suggests God’s protective presence both behind and before the psalmist.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states God has beset the psalmist behind and before and laid His hand upon him, indicating comprehensive protection.

questions.question: In Psalms 139:17-18, the psalmist compares God's thoughts to what natural imagery to convey their vastness?
questions.correctAnswer: Sand on the seashore
questions.explanation: The psalmist states God's thoughts are more numerous than the sand, illustrating their infinite and precious nature.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the theme of God’s intimate knowledge of the individual as expressed in Psalms 139:1-4?
questions.correctAnswer: Hebrews 4:13
questions.explanation: Hebrews 4:13 states that nothing in all creation is hidden from God’s sight, paralleling Psalms 139’s emphasis on God’s exhaustive knowledge.

questions.question: Psalms 139:8 uses 'hell' (Sheol in Hebrew). How does this reflect the ancient Israelite understanding of the afterlife compared to later Christian theology?
options: Sheol was a shadowy place of the dead, not necessarily a place of torment as in Christian hell
Sheol was a fiery place of punishment identical to Christian hell
Sheol was a heavenly paradise for the righteous
Sheol was considered a physical location in the underworld
questions.correctAnswer: Sheol was a shadowy place of the dead, not necessarily a place of torment as in Christian hell
questions.explanation: Ancient Israel viewed Sheol as the abode of the dead, a neutral place, differing from the later Christian concept of hell as a place of punishment.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'thine eyes did see my substance, yet being unperfect' in Psalms 139:16 within biblical anthropology?
options: It denotes God's knowledge of the individual even before birth and imperfection
It implies humans are born perfect but fall into sin later
It symbolizes God's forgetfulness of human faults
It refers to the physical weakness of infancy
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes God's knowledge of the individual even before birth and imperfection
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God's foreknowledge and intimate involvement in human formation from the earliest, imperfect stage.

questions.question: How does the psalmist’s request in Psalms 139:23-24 relate to the prophetic tradition in the Hebrew Bible regarding self-examination and repentance?
options: It aligns with the prophetic call for inward holiness and seeking God’s guidance
It rejects the need for repentance
It focuses solely on external ritual purity
It anticipates the destruction of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It aligns with the prophetic call for inward holiness and seeking God’s guidance
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to examine his heart and lead him, paralleling prophetic themes of repentance and divine guidance found throughout the Hebrew Scriptures.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 139 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 139 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:1, what is one attribute of God revealed in this verse?
options: God searches and knows us intimately
God only knows our outward actions
God is unaware of human thoughts
questions.correctAnswer: God searches and knows us intimately
questions.explanation: Psalms 139:1 states, 'O LORD, thou hast searched me, and known me,' revealing God's intimate knowledge. This is consistent with Jeremiah 17:10, Hebrews 4:13, 1 Chronicles 28:9, and Proverbs 15:3, affirming God's omniscience.

questions.question: What does Psalms 139:7 teach about the omnipresence of God?
options: One cannot escape the Spirit and presence of God
God is present only in holy places
God is limited to the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: One cannot escape the Spirit and presence of God
questions.explanation: The verse asks, 'Whither shall I go from thy spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence?' showing God's omnipresence. This aligns with Jeremiah 23:24, Acts 17:27-28, Proverbs 15:3, and Matthew 28:20.

questions.question: Psalms 139:13 uses the phrase 'fearfully and wonderfully made.' What theological truth does this express?
options: God's creative work in the womb is intentional and marvelous
The body is unimportant to God
questions.correctAnswer: God's creative work in the womb is intentional and marvelous
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's intentional and marvelous creation of human life, supporting doctrines of Imago Dei and sanctity of life as in Genesis 1:27, Jeremiah 1:5, Job 31:15, and Luke 1:41.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139:16 describe God's knowledge of human beings before birth?
options: God saw all members written in His book before they existed
God only knows humans after birth
Humans are unknown to God before birth
God's knowledge is limited by time
questions.correctAnswer: God saw all members written in His book before they existed
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'in thy book all my members were written,' indicating God's foreknowledge and sovereign design, consistent with Isaiah 44:24, Ephesians 1:4, Psalm 71:6, and Jeremiah 1:5.

questions.question: What does Psalms 139:23-24 request of God regarding the psalmist's heart and ways?
options: That God search, know, try, and lead in the way everlasting
That God ignore the psalmist's faults
questions.correctAnswer: That God search, know, try, and lead in the way everlasting
questions.explanation: These verses express a plea for divine examination and guidance, reflecting themes in Proverbs 3:5-6, Psalm 25:4-5, Jeremiah 29:11, and John 14:6 about God's leadership and salvation.

questions.question: Which doctrine about God's knowledge is emphasized in Psalms 139:4?
options: God knows every word before it is spoken
questions.correctAnswer: God knows every word before it is spoken
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'there is not a word in my tongue, but, lo, O LORD, thou knowest it altogether,' affirming God's exhaustive omniscience, as also shown in Isaiah 65:24, Matthew 10:29-31, Hebrews 4:13, and Luke 12:7.

questions.question: Psalms 139:8 states that God is present even in the realms of death. What eschatological truth does this support?
options: God's presence transcends death and the grave
Death is the end of God's knowledge
God is limited to earthly existence
questions.correctAnswer: God's presence transcends death and the grave
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'if I make my bed in hell, behold, thou art there,' affirming God's continual presence post-mortem, consistent with Revelation 1:18, Hebrews 2:14-15, Psalm 23:4, and John 11:25-26.

questions.question: In Psalms 139:19-20, what is the psalmist's attitude toward the wicked who oppose God?
options: He desires their removal and distance from himself
He wishes to reconcile with them
questions.correctAnswer: He desires their removal and distance from himself
questions.explanation: The psalmist says, 'depart from me therefore, ye bloody men,' showing rejection of the wicked, consistent with Proverbs 6:16-19, Romans 12:9, Psalm 1:6, and 2 Thessalonians 1:6-9.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139:14 describe the works of God in relation to human beings?
options: Marvellous are God's works and the soul knows it well
God's works are unknown and hidden
Human beings are insignificant to God
God's works are flawed and incomplete
questions.correctAnswer: Marvellous are God's works and the soul knows it well
questions.explanation: The verse praises God's marvelous creation of humans, supporting doctrines of divine craftsmanship and human dignity found in Isaiah 64:8, Ephesians 2:10, Colossians 1:16, and Genesis 2:7.

questions.question: What does Psalms 139:5 mean when it says, 'Thou hast beset me behind and before, and laid thine hand upon me'?
options: God's protection and guidance encompass all directions
God only watches from a distance
questions.correctAnswer: God's protection and guidance encompass all directions
questions.explanation: This verse portrays God's comprehensive care and sovereignty, paralleling Psalm 32:8, Isaiah 41:10, John 10:28-29, and Romans 8:38-39.

questions.question: According to Psalms 139:17-18, how are God's thoughts toward the psalmist described?
questions.correctAnswer: Precious and numerous beyond counting
questions.explanation: The psalmist values God's thoughts highly, saying they are 'more in number than the sand,' reflecting God's love and care, as in Psalm 40:5, Romans 8:28, Jeremiah 29:11, and 1 Corinthians 13:4-7.

questions.question: What theological concept is emphasized by the imagery in Psalms 139:9-10 about the wings of the morning?
options: God's guidance and presence reach even the farthest places
God is limited to certain locations
Humans can hide from God in nature
The sea is separate from God's control
questions.correctAnswer: God's guidance and presence reach even the farthest places
questions.explanation: The imagery communicates God's omnipresence and guidance, consistent with Psalm 23:4, Isaiah 43:2, Matthew 28:20, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What does Psalms 139:6 suggest about human understanding of God's knowledge?
options: God's knowledge is too wonderful and high for humans to attain
God's knowledge is simple and easy to grasp
questions.correctAnswer: God's knowledge is too wonderful and high for humans to attain
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'Such knowledge is too wonderful for me; it is high, I cannot attain unto it,' highlighting divine transcendence, echoed in Isaiah 55:8-9, Romans 11:33, Job 11:7, and 1 Corinthians 2:16.

questions.question: How does Psalms 139:11-12 describe God's relationship to darkness and light?
options: Darkness and light are alike to God, and darkness does not hide from Him
God only sees in the light
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness and light are alike to God, and darkness does not hide from Him
questions.explanation: The psalmist says, 'the darkness hideth not from thee,' showing God's omniscience transcends physical conditions, consistent with John 1:5, 1 John 1:5, Isaiah 42:16, and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: What does the psalmist express in Psalms 139:21-22 regarding those who hate God?
options: He hates them with perfect hatred and counts them as enemies
He is indifferent to those who hate God
questions.correctAnswer: He hates them with perfect hatred and counts them as enemies
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares, 'I hate them with perfect hatred,' signaling righteous opposition to evil, consistent with Proverbs 8:13, Romans 12:9, Psalm 97:10, and Revelation 2:6.
